tags: i love seeing lily as a little more...... mean
summary:
I don't even hate James Potter, I just honestly don't care about him. 
He's..... not interesting. He was a bully, then maybe he...
body:
I don’t even hate James Potter, I just honestly don’t care about him.

He’s….. not interesting. He was a bully, then maybe he felt sorry about it or maybe he didn’t. He died to protect his family like 90% of Tragic Dad Figures, yeeeeeeeah.

(And Lily is written like a Tragic Perfect Mother Figure which is boring too)

blog.name: eisthenameofme

blog.description: This will probably just be an amalgamation of things that interest me. It may also include fragments of my writing or art. It'll probably be wierd. As you may have already guessed, I'm E. Pronouns: I'm agender and generally use they/them pronouns, but anything that doesn't imply I have a gender (including neo-pronouns, it, etc.) is fine.

tags: anyway this annoys me so much on a worldbuilding level
what fuckkng fun could be had
also it literally makes me want to study dark magic in real life
which was very likely not the intended side effect
summary: my Hot Take on dark magic
body:
my Hot Take on dark magic

Okay so “dark arts” is already a really fucking nebulus term and arguably in large part more politically than academically defined*, and often like any type of magic that’s either particularly dangerous or mysterious seems to end up getting lumped in. It’s also reasonable to assume that “the dark arts” is its own brach of magic* (Snape’s speech about it having many everchanging branches), it’s just doublful that the larger magical community/Britain’s political system understands it enough to even have a proper conversation about it, to the extent that it may more reasonably be considered *several branches of magic, and may include some magic more reasonably suited to other branches that just got lumped in because it scared people. Notable that if we look at any potential defining features of dark magic - meaningfully harmful, mysterious, dangerous- theres nothing preventing it from operating in other magical systems (malevolently designed charms, abjectly harmful transfiguration, etc) so in addition to some “scary” magic from other fields being lumped in, and especially considering how nebulous and ever changing and maleable the dark arts can apparently be, it wouldn’t be unreasonable to suggest that part of this is becasue it’s so suited to drawing from and mixing other magical fields, which may also explain it evidently being so frequently dangerous- you’re mixing arguably at least two (itself as a base + another branch for methodology) (most of the time) magical fields with their own methodology and if they don’t contrast each other badly it’s still likely rather experimental (experimental especially considering how frequently it changes).

I say that it’s a nebulous term more politically than acadmically defined for several reasons. Firstly morals are not absolute, and it’s very clearly meant to mean “immoral magic”. It also seems unclear in this case whether “intentionally malevolent” means the inventor of the spell, the caster, or both together; the latter would make the most sense, seeing as the caster could hypothetically cast literally any spell with malevolent intent and someone attemting to make a malevolent spell could end up creating something very suited to benevolenet purposes; this isn’t how we see dark magic practically defined, though (its also worth noting what is meant by “malevolent intent”, but that’s another matter). Even the “worst” curses could be used for what is almost unquestioningly considered benevent, eg: the killing curse used as a painless euthenasia (this is where the question of what is intentionally malevolent comes up again - is it malevolent to want someone/something dead under literally any circumstances? All that’s required of the killing curse is that you have to mean it, but nothing is said regarding your motivation therin). The imperious curse is only that if you consider controling the actions of others to be inherently harmful- not necessarily something I personally disagree with, but certainly debatable, especially depending on your definition of harm and considering some of the things our society deems reasonable in various contexts. Soul magic is only seen in the context of horcruxes, but seems to hold a very strong taboo and be considered dark, regardless of whether horcruxes could be the only relevent use of it- it seems to be  considered dark and taboo in large part because very little is known about it (and ironically that may be  the very reason so little is known about it). I say that the definition we are given is more political than academic because the primary way it seems to discussed in wizarding britain is not suited to academic study, so much as it seems to be a matter of legalization.

The problem with having a brach of magic centered around immorality is that morality itself is not absolute. The watsonian conclusion this leads me to is that what is called dark magic is, at least in wizarding britain, very poorly understood to the point where it may actually be comprised of multiple kinds of magic, very likely includes at least several spells better categorized elsewhere, and is, as it is presently categorized, both ill suited to academic study and, given the fear surrounding it, unlikely to be studied even in a circuitous manner in order to aid in it’s prevention. It also makes me rather dubious about a lot of the other information we have on dark magic from apparently unreliable narrators, like the idea that all dark magic somehow leads to some tangible/innate personal corruption.

I may edit/update this later. Can you tell I’ve thought far too much about this

Draco: Look, Harry, dear, there are a...
body:
Draco: Don't you dare put that thing on my tree!
Harry: But it's my favourite ornament!
Draco: Look, Harry, dear, there are a lot of reasons for a divorce and putting a hippogriff on a Christmas tree is one of them

blog.name: fantasticpotterandwheretofindem
blog.title: Harry Potter
blog.description: Ron is my heart and soul

body:
Chubby!Ron

What I love about Chubby!Ron is that it would make Molly so proud. Think about it. This is a family that can barely get by. I think she would be really happy for a reminder that her family eats properly despite their money issues. The fact that her son can eat enough to have some chub on his sides and cheeks is her own sign that no matter the second hand clothes and books, she has done well with them. That just warms my heart so much.

tags: harry potter and the prisoner of azkaban
summary: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban - J. K. Rowling
title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban - J. K. Rowling
body:
“Happiness can be found, even in the darkest of times, if one only remembers to turn on the light”

Mon marathon Harry Potter continue ! C’est vrai qu’en recommençant la saga, j’ai cru naïvement que je saurais contrôler ma soif de magie, mais j’avais bien entendu tort. Surtout lorsque m’attend Harry Potter et le prisonnier d’Azkaban, qui est très certainement mon volume préféré de la série. 



Qu’est-ce que ça raconte ? 

Après avoir vaincu le Basilic, Harry est rentré à Privet Drive, le cœur dans les talons à l’idée de quitter Poudlard et ses amis. Comme si son été chez les Moldus n’était pas encore assez terrible, il apprend qu’il va devoir supporter la tante Marge pendant une semaine ! Harry prend sur lui, supporte jour après jour les remarques cruelles qu’elle fait sur son éducation, son absence d’intelligence, mais il ne parvient pas à se contrôler quand, le dernier jour de son séjour, la tante Marge insulte son père décédé. Après lui avoir accidentellement jeté un sort, il prend ses affaires de magie et quitte la maison de son oncle et de sa tante, sans savoir vraiment où aller. C’est alors que le Magicobus le recueille et le dépose à Londres, au Chaudron Baveur. 

Quelques semaines plus tard, Harry retrouve la famille Weasley et Hermione, et surprend une conversation entre les parents de son meilleur ami Ron : un dangereux individu du nom de Sirius Black s’est échappé de la prison la mieux gardée du monde des sorciers…et il en aurait après Harry. 

La nouvelle année qui attend Harry à Poudlard s’annonce encore une fois peu ordinaire : procès d’hippogriffe, carte des Maraudeurs, Détraqueurs, matchs de Quidditch, visites à Pré-au-Lard, Animagi, identités secrètes et vérités révélées rythmeront la troisième année de Harry Potter. 


Comme je l’écrivais un peu plus tôt, ce troisième volet de Harry Potter est vraisemblablement mon petit chouchou. Et pour cause, on y découvre deux de mes personnages préférés de la saga : Remus Lupin et Sirius Black. Remus, loup-garou, professeur compétent, attachant, attaché à ses élèves, et Sirius, emprisonné à tort pendant douze ans dans une prison qui menaçait littéralement d’aspirer son âme, torturé par l’erreur qu’il a faite et qui a entraîné la mort de James et Lily, assoiffé de vengeance. Ces deux personnages permettent d’accéder à un autre Poudlard, le Poudlard des Maraudeurs, le Poudlard où Peter n’avait pas encore trahi les Potter, où Sirius n’était pas en prison pour un crime qu’il n’avait pas commis… 

On découvre aussi les Patronus, et combien de fois ai-je voulu savoir à quoi aurait pu ressembler le mien ? 

Une fois de plus, ce tome est très rythmé et j’ai succombé à mes démons d’antan, c’est-à-dire lire ce livre en moins de 24h, à grand renfort de chocolat, de thé et de plaid. 


Vous voulez l’acheter ? J’avais repéré cette magnifique édition à la boutique 9 ¾ de King’s Cross, et j’ai commandé l’ensemble des livres sur Amazon.

Après avoir vaincu le Basilic, Harry est rentré à Privet Drive, le cœur dans les talons à l’idée de quitter Poudlard et ses amis. Comme si son été chez les Moldus n’était pas encore assez terrible, il apprend qu’il va devoir supporter la tante Marge pendant une semaine ! Harry prend sur lui, supporte jour après jour les remarques cruelles qu’elle fait sur son éducation, son absence d’intelligence, mais il ne parvient pas à se contrôler quand, le dernier jour de son séjour, la tante Marge insulte son père décédé. Après lui avoir accidentellement jeté un sort, il prend ses affaires de magie et quitte la maison de son oncle et de sa tante, sans savoir vraiment où aller. C’est alors que le Magicobus le recueille et le dépose à Londres, au Chaudron Baveur. 

Quelques semaines plus tard, Harry retrouve la famille Weasley et Hermione, et surprend une conversation entre les parents de son meilleur ami Ron : un dangereux individu du nom de Sirius Black s’est échappé de la prison la mieux gardée du monde des sorciers…et il en aurait après Harry. 

La nouvelle année qui attend Harry à Poudlard s’annonce encore une fois peu ordinaire : procès d’hippogriffe, carte des Maraudeurs, Détraqueurs, matchs de Quidditch, visites à Pré-au-Lard, Animagi, identités secrètes et vérités révélées rythmeront la troisième année de Harry Potter. 


Comme je l’écrivais un peu plus tôt, ce troisième volet de Harry Potter est vraisemblablement mon petit chouchou. Et pour cause, on y découvre deux de mes personnages préférés de la saga : Remus Lupin et Sirius Black. Remus, loup-garou, professeur compétent, attachant, attaché à ses élèves, et Sirius, emprisonné à tort pendant douze ans dans une prison qui menaçait littéralement d’aspirer son âme, torturé par l’erreur qu’il a faite et qui a entraîné la mort de James et Lily, assoiffé de vengeance. Ces deux personnages permettent d’accéder à un autre Poudlard, le Poudlard des Maraudeurs, le Poudlard où Peter n’avait pas encore trahi les Potter, où Sirius n’était pas en prison pour un crime qu’il n’avait pas commis… 

On découvre aussi les Patronus, et combien de fois ai-je voulu savoir à quoi aurait pu ressembler le mien ? 

Une fois de plus, ce tome est très rythmé et j’ai succombé à mes démons d’antan, c’est-à-dire lire ce livre en moins de 24h, à grand renfort de chocolat, de thé et de plaid. 


Vous voulez l’acheter ? J’avais repéré cette magnifique édition à la boutique 9 ¾ de King’s Cross, et j’ai commandé l’ensemble des livres sur Amazon.

trail.content_raw:
“Happiness can be found, even in the darkest of times, if one only remembers to turn on the light”

Mon marathon Harry Potter continue ! C’est vrai qu’en recommençant la saga, j’ai cru naïvement que je saurais contrôler ma soif de magie, mais j’avais bien entendu tort. Surtout lorsque m’attend Harry Potter et le prisonnier d’Azkaban, qui est très certainement mon volume préféré de la série.

summary: The year is 2028, thirty years after the battle of Hogwarts. Most of the children of the trio, and others at the battle, have...
body:
The year is 2028, thirty years after the battle of Hogwarts. Most of the children of the trio, and others at the battle, have become adults. The trio and their friends have retired to a quiet life in unknown parts of the country. YHE is a character and personal plot driven site coupled with site-wide events and potential site-wide plots.
Home | Alias Sorting | Face Claims | Job Claims | Want Ads | Discord

Mainly a shipping blog.

Naruto x Hinata (Naruto), Zelda x Link (Legend of Zelda), Cloud x Tifa (Final Fantasy 7), Phoenix x Maya (Ace Attorney), Sheldon x Amy (Big Bang Theory), Nick x Adalind (Grimm), Reggie x Betty (Archie Comics), Rick x Lisa (Macross Saga), Katniss x Peeta (Hunger Games), Arnold x Helga (Hey Arnold)

Crack/Older Ships: Ryoga x Ukyou (Ranma 1/2), Lina x Zelgadiss (Slayers), Ichigo x Rukia (Bleach)

Abandoned Ships: Olicity (CW Arrow)

summary: About the half blood prince - My time to rant
title: About the half blood prince - My time to rant
body:
So I’ve been coming along posts and theories that snape stole the potions book from James and Sirius and only wrote his name to gloat about himself
Another theory I’ve heard is that everything snape wrote in the book … He overheard it from James or something

Please stop for a moment … Stop glorifying every damn wrong thing that James did … He did couple of wrong things too
And I agree that snape is a flawed character too but that doesn’t allow us to hand over his knowledge and creativity at potions to someone else

Snape was a freakin potions teacher at Hogwarts …. He was genuinely good at making potions. He had great interest in the subject and hence why he came up with interesting solutions and short cuts

Please stop giving all of snape’s credit to James ….
As for me … Snape is genuinely one of my favourite characters … I love him and … Ppl trying to make him seem as an idiot or liar … It hurts me …

Please stop giving the credit of the HALF BLOOD Prince to anyone else
